In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Sure, here is a simple implementation of your requirement in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(str, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(str)
    result = ""
    for word in words
        if length(result) + length(word) > text_width - 1 # -1 to account for space
            result *= "\n"
        elseif !isempty(result)
            result *= " "
        end
        result *= word
    end
    return result
end
```

Here's an example of how this function can be used:

```julia
println(wrap_string("This is a simple string with some words. This function wraps the text to a certain width.", 10))
```

In this example, the `wrap_string` function splits the input string into words and checks if adding each word would exceed the maximum allowed length. If it does, it starts a new line in the resultant string. Otherwise, it just appends the word to the current line. Note that this code also includes a small check to avoid adding a space at the beginning of the first line.
